title: Who will be elected governor of North Carolina in 2020?
preds: Very likely Trump will win the state and give the down ticket a boost.
I’ll go with the group on this one 😃
Cooper still up big means he should see this one all the way through.

"As for North Carolina, we considered moving Cooper's race against Lt. Gov. Dan Forest to Likely Democratic, given Cooper's frequent double-digit leads in the polls. But the state has a long list of competitive races this year, including the presidential contest, so to be cautious, we're keeping the race at Lean Democratic." https://www.usnews.com/news/elections/articles/2020-10-29/analysis-republicans-maintain-edge-in-governor-races I think they're being a little conservative given that most polling shows Cooper with a roughly +10 lead, but they do make some good points.

"Cooper, who narrowly won in 2016, faces Lt. Gov. Dan Forest in a bid for a second term. Cooper has made a series of tough decisions due to the coronavirus, and so far, North Carolinians seem to be giving him credit for his efforts. Recent polls show Cooper ahead by between five and 19 points, a margin well ahead of Democratic presidential nominee Biden in the state. Forest has tried to raise his profile by suing Cooper over his handling of the virus; the lieutenant governor has also questioned the effectiveness of masks and said he will not mandate them if he wins. Cooper has responded with TV ads chastising Forest for holding crowded, in-person events. For now, Cooper’s approach seems to be serving him well. Indeed, in multiple polls, a durable 8% to 12% of voters indicate support for both Trump and Cooper. Because North Carolina is a purple state, we’re not ready to move this race to Likely Democratic, but it’s clearly leaning in Cooper’s direction." https://www.usnews.com/news/elections/articles/2020-10-13/analysis-republicans-look-poised-to-maintain-edge-in-governors-mansions

There was an enormous change in the polls after the revelation that Cunningham sexted a married woman whose husband is in the Army Reserves.  The Army is now investigating (per Barr or Trump's orders?)  This is a black swan event and some polls posted tonight on 538 are now even.  The next few days will likely be crucial.
The recent news about his sexting has hurt his poll numbers in this evangelical state.
Cooper maintains a solid and consistent lead. Polling quality is not great but the message is the same across the board. [1] [1] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/governor/north-carolina/

From a Cook Political report update out today: "In North Carolina, Democratic Gov. Roy Cooper remains the favorite for reelection with a hefty fundraising advantage — and steady polling lead — over Republican Lt. Gov. Dan Forest. Forest has come under fire for remarks he's made disparaging the efficacy of mask-wearing that Democrats have exploited. The closeness of the Tar Heel State as the ultimate swing state this election means this one may never be comfortably put away for Cooper. Still, he is running the best of any statewide Democrat on the ballot, and it remains in the Lean Democratic column." https://cookpolitical.com/analysis/governors/governors-overview/governors-updates-rating-changes-missouri-and-vermont
Cooper is popular in a state tuning blue.
Cooper remains up by 9.67 points in recent spout of Monmouth polls.
All polls since May show Cooper leading (and only one was a tie).
Updating.  The Dem is very solid in all polls, up by 10%
Upping this from 90 to 100. Going all in on Cooper.
Democrat is leading large still as of this writing
Cooper still up by double digits in recent polling, no sign he won't finish strong.
Consistently polling higher and has opened up a gap in recent weeks.
Cooper has been up double digits in polls for months https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/governor/north-carolina/.

Cooper's COVID response only seems to be helping him in the polls [1], and he consistently leads Forest, who was just forced to drop his sideshow lawsuit [2]. [1] https://spectrumlocalnews.com/nc/charlotte/politics/2020/08/13/president--senate-candidates-in-close-race-for-nc [2] https://www.wunc.org/post/cooper-wins-key-ruling-covid-19-legal-fight-forest

Maintaining my current projection. Forest hasn't been up in a single poll this year (he did come out even in one June poll), and most pollsters have Cooper up by double digits. With less than 80 days left before the election and Cooper maintaining his demanding lead for months with no apparent momentum change upcoming, it would be a dramatic upset for Forest to pull this one out. I'm not saying it's impossible, NC is definitely purple leaning red in many places and polls are not always right on the money, but the data suggests it won't be a kind November for the Republican candidate.
A GOP candidate has only won the gubernatorial race 3 times since 1980. Roy Cooper has maintained his popularity since winning in 2016.
The Democrat (Cooper), has maintained a solid 10 point advantage in the RCP averages.
Marist A+ polling shows Cooper's lead is now approaching 20%.

Minority Governor elected due to his rival at three time.  Republican majorities in both houses.  School issue will hurt him with voters who cannot telework.  These are the most reliable Dem voters and they may stay home

Cooper extends his lead in polling over Forest [1] while also continuing to receive positive praise for his C19 response - even as cases increase [2].  One thing to keep an eye on is the continuation of Federal assistance for the unemployed due to C19, and the impact on NC voters. For example, NC households are a total of  $253 million [3] behind in utility payments. For now, Gov. Cooper is getting a pass, but if the burden increases and households continue to have to make tough choices, they may sour on the incumbent.  [1] https://www.politicsnc.com/cooper-is-up-20-cunningham-up-9-and-biden-up-7/
[2] https://www.wral.com/coronavirus/former-gov-perdue-cooper-staying-focused-on-pandemic-but-trump-wasting-time-on-politics/19210805/
[3] https://www.wral.com/coronavirus/ward-lenz-helping-households-keep-the-lights-on-now-and-later/19211339/
Updated from polling data.  The Dem has consistently polled over 50%.
Roy Cooper holds a 5 to 11 point lead depending on the polling source.
Roy Cooper is an incumbent, popular, and leading in the polls. Forest is not well known among NC politicians and is polling underwater in the current climate.
Poor Senate candidate hurting gop state vote, anti-trump sentiment, low gop turnout

I'm trying something different with this prediction - I'm trying to teach myself how to use Bayes' Theorem. My intent is that this will establish a reasonable baseline *from which to adjust* that is more accurate than starting with a simple 50/50 and adjusting from there. Here is a great video on Bayes' Theorem and how to use it (1 of 3): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XQoLVl31ZfQ&vl=en I intend to take the "outside view" by using National gubernatorial elections as the initial posterior, and then use data specific to NC, and then to Democrates in NC, as subsequent priors. I'm drawing data from here: http://governors.rutgers.edu/testing/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Incumb_Chart_Word_2013.pdf And here is my poor attempt at math, using ratios: Did incumbent at the national level win?     901 : 1250  Did incumbent win in the SE?    17.2425 : 25 ****Note that 1971 marked a term limit change in NC so that the incumbent could serve more than one term - max of two consecutive terms***** Did the incumbent in NC, since 1971, win reelection? 4 : 6 Did a Democratic incumbent in NC, since 1971, win reelection? 3 : 5 Plugging all this data into Bayes' Theorem yields the following: 86% chance of Cooper winning, given the above information. Obviously, this is a starting point from which to adjust and does not take in to account other relevant data, such as current voter registration, likely voter turnout, fund raising data, the incumbent's popularity, etc.  I will have to wrestle with how to use that type of information to make adjustments to the base probability of 86%. I'd welcome any thoughts on how to adjust for those factors.
The incumbent will win, with the unaffiliated votes going democratic

Looking at the history of gubernatorial races since 1948, and the percentage of times the incumbent won nationally (72.08%), then using Bayes formula to account for variance in gubernatorial races in the Southeast (68.97%), and then again for North Carolina gubernatorial races specifically (26.3%), I get to 56% in favor of Cooper. There are other factors to keep an eye on, specifically the COVID19 response and reception by voters. Another factor is individual contributions to each candidate. So far those favor Cooper (very) roughly 8:1.
Four of the last five governors in North Carolina have been Democrats.

Considering we (I live in NC) ousted the GOP Governor over transgender bathroom bill and the resulting shame - yet NC still managed to maintain GOP control overall in the state.  Cooper has done a commendable job handling the pandemic in a non-partisan manner During an election year in a swing state, guided in part by the endless well of doctors and scientists on hand locally (Duke, UNC, Wake Forest, etc).  His team has also done an excellent job of avoiding resorting to partisan tactics or threats when groups presented challenges in court to his pandemic restrictions (Bars, churches, gyms, etc).  He is also a moderate and has a calm and pleasant demeanor.  All of this, IMO, will continue to ensure his place as Governor.
Recent polls show the democratic candidate leading slightly, but within the margin of error.  Registration about democratic votes statewide is up.
The GOP is so warped at this pt...voters will stampede for the moderate democrat, Biden.

https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/governor/north-carolina/ Yesterday's poll has Cooper winning by a margin of 3% — significantly smaller than the 11% margin he had in the most recent prior poll from June 30th. Worth noting, however, that the pollster does not yet have a rating on RealClearPolitics, and that this is a singular poll.
Republican state but Republican senator hard pressed on re-election.
Siena College/NYT (A+) has Democratic incumbent Roy Cooper with a double digit lead. [1] [1]https://scri.siena.edu/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/NC0620-Crosstabs062520H.pdf

Current polls have Cooper up by over 10 points (https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2020/governor/nc/north_carolina_governor_cooper_vs_forest-6750.html) and the state is leaning Biden (https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2020/president/nc/north_carolina_trump_vs_biden-6744.html)
Biden leading trump and cooper leading the gop  candidate for governor.  These leads seem likely to hold up.

Cooper is one of the nation's most popular governors. He is presently leading Forest by an average--an AVERAGE--of 17 points! I can always back this off later but right now it's looking about as good as it can for Cooper. I'm willing to bet that only 1 in 50 governors ahead by 17 points end up losing their elections.
Solid lead by Dem incumbent, in what will be a Democratic wave year. https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/governor/north-carolina/
Doubling the chances for Dems here.
Taking a more conservative stance until more of the crowd weighs in. Good research done by all thus far: https://www.270towin.com/2020-governor-election/
As a start Cooper is ahead in the polls. Not sure Trump can come back . The state seems very split and there is still a long way to go however

State still has republican majoritys in both houses.  Cooper’s win was a repudiation of McCrory.  While Coopers response to CoVID is popular in dem circles it is not resonating in most counties.  Unlikely, republicans will vote against their candidate this time.
Cooper is very popular in a state that is not as red as it used to be. He should win in a landslide.
The democrat incumbent has a double digit lead and his leadership during the covid19 pandemic has been approved of by 70% of people in recent polls.

Been around a long time, Gov. Roy Cooper has significant name I'd, handling things well. A plus 15 approval rating and NC is in play for Dems in US Senate and Presidential races which equates to campaign resources all around.
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/governor/north-carolina/ More than 10 points difference in polls
